fields.text: Fill in the blank with the correct verb form (one word only): If he _____ (study) harder, he would have passed the exam.
fields.explanation: Use 'had + past participle' (had studied) for third conditional sentences about past hypothetical situations.

fields.text: Change this sentence to passive voice (one word only for the verb): 'The committee is considering your application.' (Use 'being' in your answer)
fields.explanation: The passive form requires 'be' + past participle. For present continuous, use 'is being considered'.

fields.text: Correct the verb in this sentence (one word only): 'Neither of the students have completed their assignment.' (Change 'have' to...?)
fields.explanation: 'Neither' is singular, so it requires the singular verb 'has' instead of 'have'.

fields.text: Combine these sentences using 'which' or 'that' (one word only): 'The book was very interesting. I read it yesterday.' (Use: book ____ I read)
fields.explanation: Use 'that' or 'which' to combine the sentences. Both are correct, but 'that' is more common in defining clauses.

fields.text: Replace 'In spite of the fact that' with one word that means the same: '___ it was raining, we went for a walk.'
fields.explanation: 'Although' is a more concise way to express contrast, meaning the same as 'in spite of the fact that'.

fields.text: Rewrite this sentence in the passive voice (one word only for the verb): 'Someone should have told him the truth.' (Use: He should have ____)
fields.explanation: The passive form of modal perfect is 'modal + have been + past participle'.

fields.text: Complete the third conditional (one word only): 'If she ____ (leave) earlier, she wouldn't have missed the train.'
fields.explanation: The third conditional requires 'had + past participle' in the if-clause.

fields.text: Change to reported speech (one word only): 'I will help you tomorrow,' she said. (Use: She said she ____ help me the next day.)
fields.explanation: 'Will' changes to 'would' in reported speech when the reporting verb is in the past tense.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of 'wish' (one word only): 'I wish I ____ (know) the answer to this question.' (past simple)
fields.explanation: Use past simple after 'wish' to express a present regret.

fields.text: Complete the mixed conditional (one word only): 'If I ____ (be) more careful, I wouldn't be in trouble now.' (past perfect)
fields.explanation: This mixed conditional uses past perfect in the if-clause to show a past action affecting the present.

fields.text: Complete the inversion (one word only): 'Never before ____ I seen such a beautiful sunset.' (auxiliary verb)
fields.explanation: Negative adverbials at the beginning of a sentence require subject-auxiliary inversion.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of 'used to' (one word only): 'I ____ (be) afraid of the dark when I was a child.' (past state)
fields.explanation: 'Used to' describes past states or habits that are no longer true.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By next year, I ____ (work) here for ten years.' (future perfect continuous)
fields.explanation: Future perfect continuous shows an action continuing up to a point in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If only I ____ (listen) to your advice yesterday.' (past perfect)
fields.explanation: 'If only' with past perfect expresses regret about the past.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I'd rather you ____ (not tell) anyone about this.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: 'Would rather' is followed by past simple when talking about preferences for other people's actions.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'It's high time we ____ (leave) if we want to catch the train.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: 'It's (high) time' is followed by past simple to say that something should be done now or in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I'd rather you ____ (not smoke) in here.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: 'Would rather' is followed by past simple when talking about preferences for other people's actions.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I wish I ____ (not eat) so much last night.' (past perfect for past regret)
fields.explanation: Use past perfect after 'wish' to express regret about the past.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If he ____ (ask) me, I would have helped him.' (past perfect in third conditional)
fields.explanation: The third conditional requires 'had + past participle' in the if-clause.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By the time you arrive, I ____ (finish) all my work.' (future perfect)
fields.explanation: Future perfect shows that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I'd rather you ____ (not tell) anyone about our conversation.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: 'Would rather' is followed by past simple when talking about preferences for other people's actions.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If I ____ (be) you, I would accept the job offer.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: The second conditional uses past simple in the if-clause to talk about hypothetical situations in the present or future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I wish I ____ (can) speak French fluently.' (past simple for present meaning)
fields.explanation: Use 'could' after 'wish' to talk about ability in the present.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By the end of this year, I ____ (work) here for five years.' (future perfect)
fields.explanation: Future perfect shows that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If I ____ (know) about the traffic, I would have left earlier.' (past perfect in third conditional)
fields.explanation: The third conditional requires 'had + past participle' in the if-clause.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I wish you ____ (stop) making that noise!' (would for annoying habits)
fields.explanation: Use 'would' after 'wish' to talk about things we would like other people to do or stop doing.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If only I ____ (not forget) my keys this morning!' (past perfect for past regret)
fields.explanation: 'If only' with past perfect expresses regret about the past.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By the time we get there, the movie ____ (already/start).' (future perfect)
fields.explanation: Future perfect shows that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I'd rather you ____ (not mention) this to anyone else.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: 'Would rather' is followed by past simple when talking about preferences for other people's actions.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If he had studied harder, he ____ (pass) the exam.' (would have + past participle)
fields.explanation: The third conditional uses 'would have + past participle' in the main clause.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I wish I ____ (not have) to work tomorrow.' (past simple for present meaning)
fields.explanation: Use past simple after 'wish' to talk about present situations we would like to be different.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By next month, she ____ (live) in Paris for ten years.' (future perfect continuous)
fields.explanation: Future perfect continuous shows an action continuing up to a point in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If only I ____ (know) the answer to that question!' (past simple for present meaning)
fields.explanation: 'If only' with past simple expresses a wish for a different present situation.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I'd rather we ____ (go) to the cinema than stay at home tonight.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: 'Would rather' is followed by past simple when talking about preferences.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By the time you read this, I ____ (already/leave).' (future perfect)
fields.explanation: Future perfect shows that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If I ____ (be) you, I would take that job.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: The second conditional uses past simple in the if-clause to talk about hypothetical situations in the present or future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I wish I ____ (can) speak Japanese fluently.' (past simple for present meaning)
fields.explanation: Use 'could' after 'wish' to talk about ability in the present.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By the end of next month, I ____ (work) here for twenty years.' (future perfect)
fields.explanation: Future perfect shows that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If I ____ (know) about the party, I would have come.' (past perfect in third conditional)
fields.explanation: The third conditional requires 'had + past participle' in the if-clause.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I wish you ____ (stop) interrupting me!' (would for annoying habits)
fields.explanation: Use 'would' after 'wish' to talk about things we would like other people to do or stop doing.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If only I ____ (not eat) so much at dinner.' (past perfect for past regret)
fields.explanation: 'If only' with past perfect expresses regret about the past.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By the time we arrive, the concert ____ (already/start).' (future perfect)
fields.explanation: Future perfect shows that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I'd rather you ____ (not tell) anyone about what happened.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: 'Would rather' is followed by past simple when talking about preferences for other people's actions.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If I ____ (be) you, I would accept their offer.' (past simple for present/future meaning)
fields.explanation: The second conditional uses past simple in the if-clause to talk about hypothetical situations in the present or future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I wish I ____ (can) play the piano like you.' (past simple for present meaning)
fields.explanation: Use 'could' after 'wish' to talk about ability in the present.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By the end of next year, we ____ (complete) the project.' (future perfect)
fields.explanation: Future perfect shows that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If she ____ (study) harder, she would have passed the exam.' (past perfect in third conditional)
fields.explanation: The third conditional requires 'had + past participle' in the if-clause.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'I wish you ____ (stop) being so pessimistic!' (would for annoying habits)
fields.explanation: Use 'would' after 'wish' to talk about things we would like other people to do or stop doing.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'If only I ____ (not spend) all my money on clothes last week.' (past perfect for past regret)
fields.explanation: 'If only' with past perfect expresses regret about the past.

fields.text: Complete with the correct form of the verb (one word only): 'By the time you get this message, I ____ (already/leave) the office.' (future perfect)
fields.explanation: Future perfect shows that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future.
